messages.text: What is the real use of the professional associations? For example, in my area there is AGU (American Geophysical Union), AMS (American meteorological society) and UGM (Mexican geophysical union), among others. I am affiliated to two of them because being a member is a requirement to participate in the anual meetings (which also require a payment for abstact submission and for attending, which I think is reasonable). Apart from giving you access to the conferences or meetings, do I get any benefit from being a member of such kind of organizations? I think the situation is similar to all the areas of academia

historically, open source contributions have been considered as having zero value for an academic career.
People say times are changing, but people have been saying that for years.

messages.text: What is valuable is having the best tools.

and also the contacts you make.
Like I have met more collaborators though open source than I ever did through my supervisors contacts or from going to conferences.

messages.text:
I think that OSS is great way to gain a reputation. And reputation is currency in academia. I made Julia an essential part of my first successful grant proposal and when I met with the program manger and asked “what did you like about the proposal?” His first response was “the Julia part” I doubt that I would have been taken as seriously without my experience on LightGraphs.jl. 

The key is to always use the OSS as a tool to do traditional research/scholarship. Nobody wants to pay for maintenance so I would never submit a proposal to fund ongoing maintenance or development of an existing OSS project. But using the experience and network you gain in OSS to lend credibility to a proposal for some novel science, that can work. Also for getting hired as a post doc or research scientist. I’m way more willing to hire someone based on their GitHub commits than their publications.

elements.text: I think that OSS is great way to gain a reputation. And reputation is currency in academia. I made Julia an essential part of my first successful grant proposal and when I met with the program manger and asked “what did you like about the proposal?” His first response was “the Julia part” I doubt that I would have been taken as seriously without my experience on LightGraphs.jl.

The key is to always use the OSS as a tool to do traditional research/scholarship. Nobody wants to pay for maintenance so I would never submit a proposal to fund ongoing maintenance or development of an existing OSS project. But using the experience and network you gain in OSS to lend credibility to a proposal for some novel science, that can work. Also for getting hired as a post doc or research scientist. I’m way more willing to hire someone based on their GitHub commits than their publications.

messages.text: To agree with Lyndon, I think putting OSS contributions on your CV and hoping the tenure committee will understand that software is much more valuable than papers not effective. But I think the indirect benefits are still worth it.

elements.text: To agree with Lyndon, I think putting OSS contributions on your CV and hoping the tenure committee will understand that software is much more valuable than papers not effective. But I think the indirect benefits are still worth it.

messages.text: Slightly more cynical take. If your code is available, people will use it. If people use it, they must cite you. If people cite you, tenure.

elements.text: Slightly more cynical take. If your code is available, people will use it. If people use it, they must cite you. If people cite you, tenure.

messages.text: So i Disney PHD publishing also my Code a few years back (not yet Julia), and unwound say that for my applications (I have tenure and I applied for professorships this year) I got very positive feedback for contributing to OSS and publishing code that contains examples of the papers.

messages.text: to add to the anecdotal evidence, I would have had a hard time getting the postdoc I am starting in January if not for the OSS contributions, my PhD topic was not well aligned. The OSS ~procrastination~ side-projects offers a broad view of adjacent research topics and avoids getting stuck in your own tunnel, which is the natural tendency of academia IMO

messages.text: Thanks, all; Very insightful

messages.text: Key thing is - make sure the code is accessible even if it's pseudocode. People get this like "ooo I need to defend my research - I'll just drop this piece", but the reality is - bad/broken code looks horrible and people remember it...(I have a mental list of authors in my field who I don't even read their work and my colleagues and me would "talk" about it). Bad code may get run - but, people with lots of citations, typically have clean or friendly enough code thats described well. Cut/tag a release for the paper so people can reproduce your results. I see a lot of people screw that up too... Write a paper then the next week destroy their examples to "improve" syntax... Paper's I've seen with the most citations that include code usually have code in the paper, and a github link. There's also the whole <https://paperswithcode.com/>

attachments.title: Reboot the Computing-Research Publication Systems
attachments.text: The virtualization of conferences due to COVID-19 has sharpened my conviction that the computing-research publication system is badly broken and in need of a serious reboot.

messages.text:
I come from a field where conference presentations are largely window dressing, and all of the prestige/credit comes from journal pubs. I can't compare, but the situation isn't rosy here either.

To my mind, the larger problem is that we seem to only have proxies for gauging academic effort and impact, whether it's conference pubs or journal pubs. Efforts that don't result in these proxies, no matter how valuable aren't rewarded. And the institutions (conferences, journals) that have power to award this proxy credit do not have incentives inline with the scientific community as a whole.

elements.text:

messages.text:
Question! Whenever you take notes on a paper, what sort of sections do you have? Generally, in my notes I have found it useful to categorize components into the following:

1. General Insights
2. Methods
3. Conclusions
4. Themes/topics
How do you all take notes on papers? If you could provide examples of your notes, that would be great to see! Thank you. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Question! Whenever you take notes on a paper, what sort of sections do you have? Generally, in my notes I have found it useful to categorize components into the following:

Writing proposals helps formulate my thoughts.  Also I feel like referencing a Julia package or two I made in there that I’ve used to help in my research so there’s that, and uploading my project repositories to GitHub and creating READMEs that explain all my results so far in detail is a godsend for writing and referencing to things, even if the evaluators don’t necessary look at them.

Do proposal evaluators look at GitHub repositories?

messages.text: Not sure how far reaching this is but there is a bit of scandal right now regarding a top finance journal. The retiring managing editor made public a list of every reviewer over the past 3 decades, how many papers they reviewed (including how many they rejected), and their average turnaround time. Naturally, this made many people very upset!

messages.text: <http://blog.jamiejquinn.com/analysing-ci-in-joss> one of my colleagues analysed JOSS papers and found (as long as there are no errors in his webscraping :smile:) that almost 80% of the repositories associated to the papers have no obvious public CI setup (none of Travis, Circle or GitHub Actions at least), that's rather concerning

attachments.title: Analysing the prevalence of continuous integration in JOSS
attachments.text: JOSS is the Journal of Open Source Software and can be considered a collection of some excellent scientific codebases. Whether they’re exemplars of good coding practices is up for debate but I wanted to know roughly how many published papers (and associated codebases) were using specifically continuous integration of some form. Luckily I have some experience scraping web pages with python and the excellent webscraping package BeautifulSoup, so I cracked out the old tutorials and set to work.
attachments.fallback: JamieJQuinn: Analysing the prevalence of continuous integration in JOSS

messages.text:
I'm doing an analysis of the packages in the General registry.  preliminary results:
* 4312 packages
* 4287 reachable (the others are probably left-padded)
* 4139 have `test/runtests.jl` (97% of the reachable ones)
* 4105 have a CI setup (96%)
* 1887 have documentation (44%), I checked for the presence of `docs/make.jl`, but some packages may have documentation outside of the repo, so this is a lower limit

messages.text:
I made a tweak to require `runtests.jl` to have more than 6 lines (6 is the default empty one generated by PkgTemplates) or multiple files:
```julia> length(report)
4312

julia> count(x->x.runtests, report)
3969```

There is an odd case that occurs from time to time that is the proceedings of a workshop/conference are out years after the venue, and so is the final version of the paper. However, the publication date refers to the conference.
With the covid many special issue and proceedings were delayed...
Of course it can also be a bug in scholar ^^

messages.text: For those of you in the UK, the EPSRC is likely to run a Research Infrastructure Software funding call in the next year (see <https://epsrc.ukri.org/files/funding/calls/2014/computational-science-and-engineering-software-for-the-future-ii/|this previous call> for an example), so it might worth thinking about some potential Julia-related projects.

messages.text: I've got the opportunity to feed into the upcoming call (only in terms of providing examples of interest and specific requirements, that may or may not be ignored...) and I'd like to make a case for pushing composable software packages rather than the siloed approach that is currently used in many areas - are there any good references/case studies for Julia-style composition of packages that I can point to in order to emphasise this is a good idea in general?

messages.text:
I am a PhD student that will be graduating soon in mathematical bio, and I'm looking at positions in industry. While I am very qualified to build eg. diffeq or agent based models and handle smallish amounts of data, in a small team, basically nobody is looking for that in industry. I have some ML experience, a conference publication in ML from my undergrad and some coursework, but not much.

The key thing I feel like I'm missing is experience with technologies like databases, large scale ML, Spark. etc. So my question is, how did ppl either learn those technologies, or convince recruiters that they are worth training?

elements.text:

I have some ML experience, a conference publication in ML from my undergrad and some coursework, but not much.

The key thing I feel like I'm missing is experience with technologies like databases, large scale ML, Spark. etc. So my question is, how did ppl either learn those technologies, or convince recruiters that they are worth training?

messages.text: Anyways, point is there's a ton of people looking exactly for people who are doing DiffEq, math modeling, and SciML in Julia and if anyone just asks I can forward some of that stuff to you.

elements.text:
I am a PhD student that will be graduating soon in mathematical bio, and I'm looking at positions in industry. While I am very qualified to build eg. diffeq or agent based models and handle smallish amounts of data, in a small team, basically nobody is looking for that in industry. I have some ML experience, a conference publication in ML from my undergrad and some coursework, but not much.

The key thing I feel like I'm missing is experience with technologies like databases, large scale ML, Spark. etc. So my question is, how did ppl either learn those technologies, or convince recruiters that they are worth training?
Anyways, point is there's a ton of people looking exactly for people who are doing DiffEq, math modeling, and SciML in Julia and if anyone just asks I can forward some of that stuff to you.

messages.text:
Workflow question: I've got a good workflow going where I have a global bibliography for everything I read.

I have a little julia package I wrote for me to add in entries at the command line, then I use Rmarkdown to create an html with clickable links to the papers.

When I start writing something for class or a project, my current workflow is to create a symbolic link to my "master" `.bib` file in the folder I'm working in. As long as I don't delete things in my global bibliography, things don't break.

This is obviously not sustainable. Aside from the fragility, the symbolic link doesn't get updated to `git`.

But I really like having all my papers in one place. How do other people solve this problem?

messages.text: From the OSF preregistration: "If you plan on transforming, centering, recoding the data, or requiring a coding scheme for categorical variables, please describe that process.". Given that 80% of the time of a typical non-trivial machine learning workflow is spent on data wrangling (and not tuning models), I wonder how OSF is planning that people answer this question. Maybe, an answer could look like "See line 100-840 of src/cleaning.jl and line 600-1010 of src/aggregation.jl".

attachments.title: Phase transition into an instanton crystal state
attachments.text: In the context of condensed matter physics, instantons may be important for the description of quantum tunneling. However, they are typically irrelevant for the description of symmetry-broken states. Here, the authors propose a variant of the spin-fermion model, which exhibits a novel thermodynamically stable phase dubbed the ``Instanton Crystal.'' The intriguing feature of this phase is the configuration of the order parameter consisting precisely of an alternating chain of instantons and anti-instantons. Another interesting feature is a first-order phase transition between the instanton crystal phase and the normal symmetry-broken phase, characterized by a stationary order parameter.
attachments.fallback: Physical Review B: Phase transition into an instanton crystal state

messages.text:
A recent submission had all three reviewers making comments about the language choice.
Reviewer 1:
> I somehow doubt the maturity of such a young language and ecosystem.
Reviewer 2:
> Selecting the Julia programming language is not well justified. I know that other programming languages can be used to perform the same tasks.
Reviewer 3 (on why it was chosen):
> reads like a pitch for the Julia programming language, which sounds inappropriate for this paper
:face_with_rolling_eyes:

elements.text:

Reviewer 1:
I somehow doubt the maturity of such a young language and ecosystem.

Selecting the Julia programming language is not well justified. I know that other programming languages can be used to perform the same tasks.

reads like a pitch for the Julia programming language, which sounds inappropriate for this paper

messages.text: I mean I discuss why we choose each of the components… I expected more to why using PostgreSQL instead of mongoDB or something (SQL/noSQL)… My response was like… we tried both GraphQL R packages and had tons of issues, the database Python package also had an issue that it would not close connections properly. Julia worked better and was a nicer dev experience… How is a knowing a plethora of other languages could have been used similarly an issue? It’s not my fault HTTP/Diana/LibPQ packages are so great or that Distributed makes it such a nice experience in HPC environments or that the error handling in Base is so nice… :joy:

messages.text:
<rant> I got kind of upset reading this. If you're comfortable using a language or tool and it's not absolutely unintelligible, nobody has the right to tell you _it was the wrong choice_.

That's like writing a poem in Chinese and then being told that you were wrong and it should have been written in Portugese.

messages.text: People think they're being practical by trying to enforce a greatest common denominator, but it ultimately ends up turning into such... ignorance... </rant>

messages.text:
I mean, in general, sure choices of language are not *wrong*. But this is about a publication.

To extend your metaphor, it's more like writing a poem in a Chinese language and then asking a magazine to publish it. If they feel that the bulk of their readership won't understand or appreciate your poem because of your choice of language, then that's a totally valid editorial reason to not publish it.

messages.text: E.g. messages.text: I have mostly transitioned from reviewer to area chair at this point and in general for NLP/ML (AI, if you prefer…) it is and has been for the last five years at least fairly standard that you recommend acceptance for maybe 1/5 or 2/5 if you are lucky for the “top” conferences.

elements.text: I have mostly transitioned from reviewer to area chair at this point and in general for NLP/ML (AI, if you prefer…) it is and has been for the last five years at least fairly standard that you recommend acceptance for maybe 1/5 or 2/5 if you are lucky for the “top” conferences.

messages.text: One observation that still stands is that more junior reviewers tend to be harsher and focus on details such as missing references or specific aspects of experiments, while senior reviewers tend to focus more on the overall paper and be slightly more lenient.

elements.text: One observation that still stands is that more junior reviewers tend to be harsher and focus on details such as missing references or specific aspects of experiments, while senior reviewers tend to focus more on the overall paper and be slightly more lenient.

Thoughts?

messages.text: This is real sad <https://www.aeaweb.org/articles?id=10.1257/jel.20201555&from=f>

attachments.title: Graduate Student Mental Health: Lessons from American Economics Departments
attachments.text: (Forthcoming Article) - We study the mental health of graduate students at 8 top-ranked economics PhD programs in the U.S. using clinically validated surveys. We find that 24.8% experience moderate or severe symptoms of depression or anxiety&mdash;more than two times the population average. Though our response rate was 45.1% and sample selection concerns exist, conservative lower bounds nonetheless suggest higher prevalence rates of such symptoms than in the general population. Mental health issues are especially prevalent at the end of the PhD program: 36.7% of students in years 6+ of their program experience moderate or severe symptoms of depression or anxiety, versus 21.2% of first-year students. 25.2% of economics students with these symptoms are in treatment, compared to 41.4% of graduate students in other programs. A similar percentage of economics students (40-50%) say they cannot honestly discuss mental health with advisers as say they cannot honestly discuss research progress or non-academic career options. Only 26% find their work to be useful always or most of the time, compared to 70% of economics faculty and 63% of the working age population. We provide recommendations for students, faculty, and administrators on ways to improve graduate student mental health.
attachments.fallback: Graduate Student Mental Health: Lessons from American Economics Departments

elements.text: This is real sad

messages.text: Depends on the job. If the industry job is a research position, you can very well go with a CV à la academic. Research positions will be similarly evaluated whether is academic, NGO, government, contractor, industry, etc. If the job is less research and more application to domain and such, probably better to just provide a brief of your research experience overall.
